title: Gailey Reservoir Walking Route

images.caption: South Staffordshire Sailing Club

images.title: Sailing on Gailey Reservoir by Row17, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sailing on Gailey Reservoir

images.title: Stephen McKay / Gailey Wharf
images.caption: Gailey Wharf, where the A5 crosses the Staffordshire & Worcestershire Canal, comprises a boat hire yard with maintenance facilities including a small crane, a lock, and a souvenir shop housed in the unusual 'Round House', formerly a toll clerk's office.

images.title: Roger  Kidd / Narrowboat near Gailey, Staffordshire
images.caption: Narrowboat near Gailey, Staffordshire. On the Staffordshire and Worcestershire Canal (opened in 1772) this boat is approaching the final bend before negotiating Rodbaston Lock. Vehicles can be seen on the M6 motorway, the noise from which makes this canal for several miles a noisy waterway to navigate, though one notices it far more when walking. Note: there is no white spot on your screen. It is a hang-glider.

images.title: Row17 / Another lock on the Staffs & Worcs
images.caption: Another lock on the Staffs and Worcs

images.title: The Spread Eagle, Gailey by Bill Boaden, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Spread Eagle pub in the village

description: These pretty reservoirs are located near the Staffordshire village of Gailey in the Penkridge area of the county. It's a nice place for a stroll with views across the water to the surrounding countryside. You can follow footpaths along the Lower and Upper Reservoir before linking up with the Staffordshire and Worcestershire Canal for some more waterside walking. The towpath will lead west to Gailey village where you'll find a pretty loch and weir. The reservoir is also the home of South Staffordshire Sailing Club so you will probably see some sailboats on the water on a fine day.
